description.text:
ANNOUNCEMENT!! The files for this model have been removed from this page, from now on the files can downloaded for free from www.MyMiniFactory.com. This page will be left for legacy purposes and I will still answer questions if posted. From now on, all my future projects will feature exclusively on www.MyMiniFactory.com.
My profile page is https://www.myminifactory.com/users/lilykill. Sorry for any inconvenience. This is the Grenade Launcher from the original Bioshock. Once printed and assembled IT comes in 2 pieceS which push, twist and lock into position as it does in the game. I still need to do some simplifying for assembly and do a full print to ensure all the tolerances are correct so some details might change. Once Im happy with the print Ill put the individual STL's up and start on the latch on magazine.
Two of the renders show what each half should look like when assembled. Like Ive already said, this probably isnt perfect until I print this out fully myself. I have also modeled the revolver, so check it out. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:329755 Follow me on twitter @ https://twitter.com/lilykill1, and instagram @ https://instagram.com/lilykill1/ and facebook @ https://www.facebook.com/Lilykill-253119598353137/ where you can stay up-to-date on my current projects and releases. If interested, join my group @ http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/design-to-print/topics where I aim to help anybody with anything I can with modeling or complex assembly like this design.

title: Motorola Droid Front Facing camera hack

description.text: I have a while before I can upgrade to the next droid phone, so I wanted to create a hack that allowed me to have a front facing camera without taking apart the phone. So this basically holds a few mirrors and allows you to use the regular camera as a front facing one as well. Its still a work in progress and you can see the camera/mirror quality isnt all that great, but I was hoping to get your feedback and make this better.

Print phonemirror.stl and phonemirror2.stl, also purchase some 1" square mirrors from jo-ann fabrics, here: http://www.joann.com/joann/catalog/productdetail.jsp?pageName=search&flag=true&PRODID=prd1826 then tape everything together. Once you have the angle of the mirror right you can use glue or something else to fasten in together permanently. possible improvement: a better solution than 4 1" mirrors (this causes a big line through the picture)

comments.text: Why don't you just make a mirror to reflect your screen so you have the full potential of the camera.. Say if you were using yahoo messenger video chat.. all you need to do is be able to see the screen.. I've used it plenty of times just gotta keep flipping the phone over.. its not that big of a deal but im sure this would work better..

A 3d printed nerf gun! It is quite powerful, much more so than an ordinary nerf gun. The components can (and should) be printed without support material. Overall it is a pleasure to make and shoot. http://youtu.be/fWqqkC2mWp4?list=UUbpQ7btFuliuTEXwwyfkYUQ

First start by printing all of the files. Then you can prep the non-printed parts. Cut a length of 3/4" CPVC just under 2 inches longer than the length of the large printed handle. line the CPVC up with the handle such that the back of the pipe is at the back of the gun. Then mark the pipe where the trigger sear extends up out of the handle. You need to cut a window in the CPVC that will allow the sear to extend up into the pipe, holding back the piston. I used a dremel to cut the rough shape and then filed it into the correct size. Once you have this window cut, you can work on the piston assembly.  
To start, drill a centered hole in the CPVC end cap just big enough for the long rod that was printed to slide smoothly into. You printed out a file called "New Piston Assembly". This print contains 4 parts, 3 of which are identical and one of which is taller and has a lip. Take one of the 3 flat washers with square holes and glue it right on the end of the long square rod you printed. Then slide the rod with washer through the end cap so that the rod goes through the hole you drilled and the washer that is glued on the end rests on the outside of the end cap. Once again, this is clarified in the first portion of the youtube video. Next, slide one long spring (or two short ones) down the piston rod so that the end of the spring rests inside the end cap. Glue another one of the 3 flat washers with square hole onto the rod, right against the spring. The final two washers from the piston assembly can then be glued together such that it looks like a cylinder with notch in the middle. This notch is for the o-ring. Make sure that when you glue these together the square holes align perfectly. Then glue this onto the end of the rod opposite from the end cap. You alternatively can first put them on the end of the rod (in the same sandwich configuration) and then glue them. You now should have something that looks like what the video shows. The final step is final assembly. Just follow the video and you should be good.  
The only pieces that aren't printed are an o-ring, some 3/4" CPVC for the cylinder, some 1/2" CPVC for the barrel, a 1/2" to 3/4" CPVC adapter, a 3/4" CPVC end cap, one hose clamp (I used another as a front sight), two springs, and a rubber band.

title: Parametric Power Adapter via Battery Contacts

description.text:
I have a cell phone with a bad USB charging jack. It's easier to drop in a powered battery blank than it is to fix the jack.
I also have cameras that won't record while 'charging' so this will allow me to record and have them plugged in. This is designed to use a Buck Converter to set the voltage at the 3.6v that most electronics uses now days.

This design is to use 2 nails as the contacts on the battery. Shove the nails into the printed battery housing and solder on the wires from the buck converter.
There are holes provided to run the wires through any edge if needed.
It is currently marked as a work in progress as I need to add the ability to add the 'keys' for batteries that aren't perfectly square.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/bp9nL4g0UwS

Now that you have a planetary gearset that functions as its own bearing, what else can you do with it? How about a large reduction in a small package: This drive gives a 91:1 gear ratio. It's much more convenient to print than the last version, and the only assembly required is placing the output ring onto the upper planets of the input.

The input is the sun gear, which has a hex opening in the bottom so you can turn it with a drill or attach it to something. The output is the whole upper ring, which has its own hex opening. You can customize this in many ways, and if you change the numbers of teeth, the resulting gear ratio will be printed on the side of the input ring (which is hopefully visible in the render). 
The torque capability of this gearset is not amazing, though it could probably be improved by changing some of the parameters like thinkness and twist. If any of you come up with an application for it, I'd love to see it in action.

comments.text:
Hi Emmett, Another great model - I have made a couple, one I have scaled down by 0.8 and made into a mount for a nema 23 motor. On the whole they run pretty well, although the printer I am using uses support material and where the gears have a collar on them it puts support material up to this - which is fine apart from in between the gears and the outer ring where the tolerance is such it leaves imperfections which ultimately cause the gears to go stiff at this point.
My question is do the collars need to be there? will it pull the drive wheel tight if removed or just wear the center pin?
I have printed loads of your other custom planetary gears without the collar and they run absolutely perfect..
Thanks, Lewis
comments.author: LewisGT

comments.text: The collars are just there to support the upper gear teeth, which aren't aligned with the lower ones. It works great with no support and a slicer that can handle bridging. In your case it may be doing more harm than good. You're welcome to tweak the scad files to suit your needs.
comments.author: LewisGT

Now my design skills were horrible back then, square shapes was about all i was good at!  I think I might take another stab at this.  I just started planning a redesign of some of my plastic mods to my simple metal.  Want to redesign my cable chaine, my fan mounts, and CLEAN up the wiring.  Its becoming a mess with all the lights and crap added over the years.
Keep your eyes peeled for this!
Sometimes simple is the best! Here is one of those times, v3 is working GREAT! and its really small and fast to print.
Print at .2 100% infill with support; rotated 90 on X

unbolt the lever with the bearing in it by removing the hex socket head screw from the top right corner; remove the sleeve, and replace with this print.  Tighten the bolt back down fairly snug.  The printed part has a slight angle built in to pitch the lever at an ideal angle.  Helps the filament stay nice and straight and helps keep it on the hobbed gear!!

NOMOON is a parametric spherical 3d-printed speaker generator created in OpenSCAD. For a demo video of NOMOON see:
http://youtu.be/UFUMgY15UOw Some additional notes are on working with NOMOON are at http://nothinglabs.blogspot.com/2014/12/project-nomoon-parametric-spherical.html. It is loosely based on my previous OpenScad speaker generator - Speakergen http://nothinglabs.blogspot.com/2014/09/speakergen-parametric-3d-printed.html. NOMOON can create spherical speaker enclosures of any volume. You can configure things like wall thickness, bass port dimensions, number of screw holes, etc. NOMOON also includes a speaker stand. If your speakers tend to rotate forward in the stands - strategic application of a rubber band can solve this.

Notes on picking a speaker driver are at: http://nothinglabs.blogspot.com/2014/12/project-nomoon-parametric-spherical.html. NE65W.stl is a pre-made file for use with the Vifa NE-65w driver (as pictured in the video). You can use a tool like this to determine optimal enclosure / port-size for a given driver:
http://www.micka.de/org/en/index.php#ideal Printing Tips Use a raft when printing this model! It might seem counter-intuitive that you can print a sphere without supports. The trick is to include a small flat area on the bottom - which the bass port conveniently provides. If you're not using a bass port - NOMOON will automatically include a flat disk on the bottom of the sphere to make it printable. The lower parts of the sphere do show some effects from "curling" - and looks a little gnarly on close inspection. Fortunately - this is the least visible part of the model. An enclosed / heated build chamber would probably help with this. I've been printing my speakers using 3 shells at 10% infill at 200 micron layer height (using silver PLA). They sound good to me - but audiophiles might want to increase thickness / infill. Stuff your speaker with polyfill (from the fabric store) to improve sound quality. Design Tips I've found holes on 3d prints tend to come out a little smaller than intended - and some speakers need holes a bit larger than their spec sheets indicate. My advice is to make the speaker mounting hole as large as practical - as opposed to as small as practical. Some speakers have terminals that get in the way of fitting in a round hole. A "makeTerminalNotch" option / associated parameters are provided in the script to account for this. Other option is to break out the file / Dremel. By default - two separate wire holes are generated - one on top (for hanging) and another at the rear of the sphere (if using the stand). You will likely need to drill out the hole a bit to make your speaker wire fit. I don't think the second small hole impacts acoustic quality that much (just set its diameter to zero to not render it). Note - if you're using a heavier speaker driver and want to hang it - the weight of the driver will cause the entire speaker to tip forward. Adding some kind of counter balance inside the speaker can address this. Other option is to try moving the wire hole a bit towards the "front" to compensate (you can do this in the script).

comments.text: Note that for certain drivers you may get better results without a port, and stuffing the box with acoustic stuffing.  (Pillow stuffing works well).  This makes an "acoustic suspension" type sealed box which has a more gradual F3 roll off than the ported box does.  You can get deeper bass with a given driver with a ported enclosure, but the box must be larger and the bass may be "boomy" rather than "tight".  Drivers with a lower QT work better in ported boxes, those with larger QT's are good candidates for sealed boxes.

title: Prusa i3 bed probe - mechanical switch parts

description.text:
After testing I've decided this method is not only not good, it makes things worse. I've left it here so you can learn from my mistake. With a bed probe your printer can compensate for an uneven bed. In theory this makes your printer a little more fire-and-forget. The probe switch connects a limit switch to a servo arm. The probe mount holds the servo under the extruder and manages cables. See pictures for explanation. This method is garbage because the servo doesn't bring the arm down to the same angle every time. The measurements are wildly different and the software thinks the bed is at a crazy angle. End result: hitting bed, damaging nozzle, printing mid-air... everything wrong you could never want. Next I'm going to try an induction probe. You can find out more about things I make at
http://marginallyclever.com
physical assembly

I used a 9g servo and a limit switch with a roller.  The roller part is not required.  The 35mm M3 screws that hold the hot end into the extruder ALSO hold the probe mount in place.  There's a recess on one side to hold the wires for the hot end and the servo out of harm's way.  
The servo arm is glued into the probe arm.  the switch is held on with a zip tie.  There is a hole in the arm used to hold the wires away from the nozzle.  
Code
The harder part is configuring your firmware.  If you are reading this then I have not yet published the blog post and linked it here.  Write to me!  Say something encouraging! :)

title: K8200/3Drag E3D v6 HotEnd extruder mount with fan

description.text:
Mount for the All-Metal E3D v6 Hot-End to Velleman K8200/3Drag standard filament extruder. I liked the original fan duct and mount from E3D-Online and wanted the HotEnd to mount on the original K8200/3Drag extruder using the original parts. Here is the version for 40mm fan. Updated: 2015.01.23:
  • Easier to print
  • Stronger grip on E3D cooler

This is a one piece replacement for the original fan mount from E3D-Online. The original K8200 M3 screws and spacers can be used to mount the cool part of E3D v6. For assembly:
  • 4x 2.9x19mm wood screws for fan (original screws are to long)
  • 2x M3x5mm screws for easy spacer mount (optional)
    • Following printing setting was used:
    ABS, layer height 0.3mm, 2 perimeters, 50% infill and brim. Tip: To get the smooth surface I use acetone and apply it with a nail brush.

description.text: Write your name on the INSIDE of the ring. Dual Extrusion supported!

Updated to Version 6:
There was a bug with the stl for the inscription part of the dual extrusion if one of the text fields is left blank. Should be fixed now, but be aware that if both fields are blank then the inscription stl generation will show an error because there is nothing to generate for dual extrusion in that case. There are a number of different rings available on thingiverse. But I hadn't seen a customizable one more complicated than a simple hoop or allowed you to inscribe a message on the inside like you see on a "real" ring. Perhaps, I just missed it. Regardless, I decided to make my own. You can specify ring size and adjust the thickness of the ring. Choose the height of the ring at the narrow end and then choose the angle of the cut of the ring leading up to the ring face. Choose an angle of zero for a ring of uniform height. There are two ways to inscribe a message. One is on the interior of the ring. Another is to print something on the flat face on the front of the coin. I've given options for the text size. Take care that you don't make the text too big to fit on the ring if you've also chosen to make the ring itself small. If you make a large ring, then the large text size should be able to fill the space. Support for Dual Extrusion is included. You can choose to fill in the text with a second color. I've uploaded an example STL file - you can't forge "The One Ring", but you can create a personalized ring for your kids.

comments.text: I love the orientation of this ring. Avoids the arching problem that happens when printing face down. I was planning on experimenting with this myself. Glad to see it works so well.

I made it for circulating water in an aquarium.
The pump is in the level of the water (no pressure and no elevation).
I made a test and the volume of water is more than 1 liter per minute (in my case).
I have a small aquarium 80 liters and it works well for me.
I believe that any kind of motor with good Power and RPM will work.
But remember you need a long shaft.
I had some issues to seal the motor shaft, now I am design a magnetic couple system for the rotor.
When done, I will put it here too.

title: Rainbow Dash Rain Boom! (Laser, Stain Glass)

description.text:
Rainbow Dash coming at ya in a laser cut. Cut this out of of different colours of plastic (Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Viloet, White, Black, and Clear).  
This was drawn in Inkscape. Download it. The different colours are divided up along different layers. Only unique thing is you will want to seperate the etching layer and cut layer for the back plane. Etch is just lasering at a lower power. Put paint (blue) into the cracks to make it work. Crazy glue (Use clear Gorilla Glue) to stick the layers together.

I made a few sketches, referenced several designs online and made the final sketch. Half the battle was making the drawing, while the other was setting up the laser cuts, colour layers, and refining the model.  
This one is scaled for the 13"x9" bed on the 15mW laser I have access to. Hope to see what this would look like on a big one!  
Enjoy!  
Photos of the final will be uploaded today or early tomorrow. It is lazzering atm.  
And Rainbow Dash, My Little Pony, and all that is owned by Hasbro. You cannot make any money off of this.

author: basra1998

description.text:
This extruder is a much improved extruder and X carriage for (pre-Prusa i3) RepRap 3D printers. While you can use each individually, they work best with each other.
  • Easy to thread and change filament. No need to loosen screws!
  • 4 linear bearings for stability and repeatability.
  • 4-screw idler block for high, uniform filament pressure.
  • Thick, heavy design rules and reinforcements throughout.
  • Beefy nut captures for all hex nuts..
  • Direction-indicating drive gear.
  • Attractive and compact.
  • Fits standard Groovemount (Arcol/Makergear/Prusa/E3D) hot ends.
    • It's easy to assemble, and accepts either a home-made hobbed bolt, or a third-party one, e.g., from here.
This is not a terribly difficult thing to build, but it will take a bit of time to source the parts and put everything together.  Take your time and be patient; the results are worth it.

• 3 8mm (608) bearings (e.g., here)
  • 1 8mm x 20mm smooth or threaded rod (idler bearing shaft)
  • 4 M4 washer (idler block)
  • 4 M4x55mm bolt, can substitute M4x60 bolts, though you may have to cut them to fit (idler block)
  • 7 M4 hex nut
  • 4 compression springs that fit a 4mm shaft, no more that 15mm fully compressed. I don't know how to specify springs.
  • Hobbed bolt, and one or two lock nuts (see below)
  • 2 8mm washers.
  • 4 M3 washer (motor mount)
  • 4 M3 x 8mm screws (motor mount)
  • 1 M3 x 8mm setscrew (motor gear). May use regular bolt if needed.
  • 1 M3 hex nut (motor gear)
  • 1 NEMA 17 stepper motor (e.g. here).
  • 16mm Forstner bit, for drilling out the hole for the hot end (e.g. here). Omit this only if you're very confident in your printer's ability to do accurate holes.

• 4 8mm (LM8UU) linear bearings (e.g., here)
  • 4 small cable (zip) ties (linear bearing mount)
  • 3 M4 x 20mm bolts (extruder mounting). Cut to fit if needed.
  • 3 M4 hex nuts (extruder mounting)
  • 1/8" diameter x 1/8" long magnet (e.g., here) if magnetic end stop is used.
  • Small piece of 1/8" plywood (extruder holder/spacer; see below)
  • 4 M3 x 15 bolts (belt clamps)
  • 4 M3 washers (belt clamps)
  • 4 M3 nuts (belt clamps)

Print the Smith's Easy Extruder.pdf file (on a 2D printer!) for reference.  
Print all of the STL parts including two belt clamps, and clean up as needed.

• You want it to be M8 x ~55. The hobbed area should start about 25mm down from the top of the head of the bolt.
  • You can buy one from Arcol in Hungary here. Mounting instructions for it here.
  • If you use the Arcol hobbed bolt you will need two M8 nylon lock nuts, or you can use these grub screw nuts instead. If you make your own bolt, you only need one nut.
  • To make one yourself, follow this tutorial.

• Using the 16mm drill bit, drill out the large hole on the bottom of the extruder block. This needs to be accurate, or the filament won't line up with the hot end when being inserted and you'll have to mess around with shaping the tip of the plastic.
  • Put three M4 hex nuts in their nut capture holes in the base of the extruder block.
  • Press the remaining four M4 nuts into the nut captures in the back of the extruder block. Just press them in so they're snug. To seat each of the four nuts, screw in a M4 x 55 screw so it pulls the nut all the way down into the capture. Try not to overtighten it and remove the screw when the nut is seated.
  • Attach the motor using the 4 M3 x 8 screws and the M3 washers. Leave it loose for now.
  • Put the set screw and its nut into the small gear part, and put that on the motor shaft. Don't tighten it down just yet, though.
  • Build the large gear shaft with the hobbed bolt, bearings, washers, and lock nut as shown in the exploded diagram in the PDF and insert it through the extruder block. Tighten the lock nut down snugly so the shaft will turn without binding.
  • Press (or hammer) the M8 x 20 shaft, with the bearing on it, into the printed idler block. Verify that the bearing turns freely.
  • Slide the motor gear on the motor shaft until it is on the same plane as the large gear. Tighten its set screw.
  • Shift the motor sideways until its gear is snug with the big gear. Tighten the two right M3 screws.
  • Tighten the left two M3 screws. If you have a ball end Allen wrench, you may be able to do this without taking the large gear off, otherwise you'll need to remove and replace the large gear to do this.
  • Put the four springs and M4 washers on the M4 x 55 bolts as shown.
  • Put these bolts through the idler block and then the extruder block. They should screw into the captured nuts. Tighten the screws down until the coils of the spring are almost touching.
  • Test your extruder (hot end not installed):
    • Hook up the motor cable to a working printer (make sure to turn the printer off first)
    • Turn on the printer and run the motor from the host console. If the motor is just buzzing, either you have a loose wire or a bad connection, or your steps_per_mm or feedrate is configured wrong
    • While the motor is running and the gear is turning in the direction pointed by the arrows, try to feed some filament in. To insert filament, press it into the hole on top of the extruder block, but don't put a ton of force on it.
    • If it won't go in, try loosening the idler block bolts
    • If it goes in but isn't being gripped, try tightening your idler block. You may also need to sand it down a few millimeters depending on the diameter of your hobbed bolt.
    • If that doesn't work, your hobbed bolt may be misaligned or somehow messed up.
    • When the idler is adjusted right, the filament should be pulled through smoothly.
  • Done!

• This part holds the hot end below the cold end.
  • A spacer may have come with your extruder if you bought one, and its hole pattern may or may not match the pattern on the bottom of the extruder block. If the holes don't line up, you can either drill yours out, or keep reading to make a new one.
  • Print the first page of the PDF, attach it to a piece of 1/8" plywood with rubber cement, and cut the plywood to match using a drill and a saw. (The overall goal is to get the outline to match the baseplate of the extruder for a better look, and also align your hot end with the filament coming through the extruder block so the filament will push through accurately.)
  • This part needs to be temperature resistant; don't try to print it!

• Attach the linear bearings to the X carriage using the cable ties. The bearings should fit snugly into the recess. The cable ties do not need to be super tight.
  • Using the same method as above for the extruder nut captures, put the four M3 belt clamp nuts into their captures.
  • If you're using magnetic/hall effect endstops, drill out the hole for your size of magnet and epoxy it in there.
  • Slide your hot end into the slot in the spacer, then use the three M4 x 20mm bolts to attach the X carriage, through the spacer, to the extruder block.
  • Slide the x carriage onto the X-axis shaft of your printer.
  • Using the M3 screws and nuts, attach the belt clamps to the X carriage and secure the belts.
  • NOTE: If you're using the Prusa Nozzle, you will have to saw out a hole for the fan mount in the middle of the X carriage. Also, make sure that the solid side of the fan guard is facing down so that air does not escape and cool your print and cause it to warp.
    • I found the quality of my prints to improve immediately and substantially after I switched to this X carriage and extruder. Flat surfaces come out really uniform, and vertical edges are flat and precise. I also like the direction-indicating arrows on the large gear; these provide some reassurance when you are loading filament that the motor is turning the right way.

This is a planar lithophane modeler which gives you more control over the boundary shape and holes.
This converts white color (255, 255, 255) to holes. http://maker.dongguk.edu/webclient/freeform_planar_lithophane.html The included sample was 3D printed by PICASSO (http://www.ipchae.com/). Since this model takes only 1 image as input, you can make a free-form planar lithophane easily.
The drawback is that the boundary lines are not that smooth. We will present one more model later which takes 2 images as input for better boundary lines. Enjoy!

I use powerpoint to modify googled free images. If you use image editors like photohop, you will have much more freedom to create lithophanes.

description.text: Introducing Pocket-Dungeons! A modular, competitive dungeon-crawl for two to six players. With modular, tile-based board design and randomized events, no two games will be alike. Dynamic, tactical game play allows for quick resolution as players control treasure-hungry dungeon delvers vying for gold and glory. This game has been designed with Pocket-Tactics in mind and the pieces and rules sets will be able to cross over and expand the depth of each range. For the Pocket-Tactics stuff, head on over here: http://www.thingiverse.com/dutchmogul/collections/pocket-tactics-sets Also, check out our blog for updates on our projects, contests and the like: illgottengames.blogspot.com/ All models were designed in Sculptris and Tinkercad Props to Thingiverse user Foolsgambit for his amazingly utilitarian trays. Don't play Pocket-Dungeons without them! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:54865

Pieces were printed 10% infill with a single shell. The characters were printed at a .10 layer height, while the tiles, counters, and doors were printed at a layer height of .30  
As for the rules, expect some updates pretty soon. The rules to the game are presented in their most simplified state, but I'll post some expansions and alternate game modes soon.

comments.text: OK, so more play, more questions.  We ran into a trap that allows a rival player to change the orientation of an adjacent dungeon tile.  In every case imaginable, this seals off a wall, almost certainly permanently trapping the delver if the rival wishes to do so.  So, I imagine this would effectively result in the delver being defeated. Would the player be stuck scheming, or just declare the delver defeated?  The other issue was that you could seal off an entire portion of the dungeon or in our case a room that contained a token that happened to be the exit making the entire scenario unwinnable for anybody (except the mage who had a backup plan in this unlikely event, only to be foiled by a mindswap with the thief).  Very interesting but brutal! Is this how it was meant to play out, or does the reorientation have to be to a legal facing?

comments.text:
Hello again ;) While playing this game we encountered (haha) a question: If a delver dies, does the player lose his treasure/hazard counters he got with this delver? Because otherwise he could start with a new delver and leave the dungeon with all his counters, which made the gameplay a bit odd in the end and forced a quite aggressive game (We played with 4 and 5 players).
Apart from that we had lots of fun to play! This troll really is a biest and if someone doesn't like you he can most likely get you out of the game. For some Delvers water tiles are also very dangerous. We especially liked the Lizard's abillity to move to any water tile, this makes the game very dynamic. In contrast to other "board games" one move is very fast and you don't have to wait for hours until you take part in the action again, which results in the promised "fast-paced" game. We will try a multiplayer-game of Pocket Tactics asap.
comments.author: Toni91

comments.text: Haha, sorry, I still need to overhaul the rules sheet :-P Yeah, when a delver dies, their treasure is left in a stack in the tile they died in. Hazard counters stay with the player though, and act as a tie breaker when treasure tokens are counted.

title: Dust Commander Cyclone Separator - Ryobi 18v Vacuum Attachment.

description.text:
I got one of these Awesomely designed Dust Commander cyclone separators for a woodworking nut of a friend for Xmas, but I thought it needed something more...
I had a motor and fan from a Ryobi One+ 18v 'dust buster', so I converted it to a press-fit vacuum unit for this cyclone separator.
(I can't remember if this fan was from the blue version or the green version Ryobi - if you're game - try and see!) Warning - this is loud! Hearing protection should be worn.
Also, this has HUGE amounts of suction for what it is!

You'll need to print one of part 1, and two of part 2.
Keep the orientation as I have it for best results.
Support is needed for part 2.
4x thin (M3) bolts and 4x approx 3mm diameter plastic screws are needed. Source the plastic screws from any old Nerf gun or toy.
I have included a couple printable base plates as well. I have not tried to make this suck up anything as yet - so use at your own risk... but if it works - please let us know!!!

description.text:
This is a spool holder that i made just for fun on tinkercad. It replaces the left back bracket on the Lulzbot AO-101. It does work, and makes switching filament easy for me. UPDATE:
I had an idea to make the washers triangular so that they can both be printed at the same time ON the AO-101.
two washer spool.stl or two with the lulzbot logo
two washer spool lulzbot.stl
from http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/hardware/printed_parts/electronics_enclosure/enclosure_top/enclosure_top-v1.1.STL

• print 2 washers or the two triangular washers
  • print a spool bushing
  • print pin and cotter pins
  • assemble with the bushing in the spool
    The cotter pins are from:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29770
    • These cotter pins are much smaller, and you may have to take an Exacto knife to them to separate the tines on the pins (i had to). Everything else printed fine, and did not need to be sanded or anything. Remove the back left bracket on you lulzbot (the bracket by the enclosure) and replace with this.
    i altered the bracket from:
    http://download.lulzbot.com/AO-101/hardware/printed_parts/stl/spool_mount_brake.stl by extending the spool mounting hole to give clearance between the bottom of the spool of filament and the power button. The washer and bushings are customized from:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:41520 Spool move fine, and has not hung up. it works. any suggestions would be cool.

title: Kato Unitrack model railroad N scale Bridge Post

description.text:
This is a bridge post for Kato Unitrack N. The top of the post is designed to fit inside the bottom of the N-gauge Kato Unitrack bedded track. They will not "click" in, but are relatively stable even in a "flying" layout, and in a fixed layout, a drop of hot melt or mounting glue will do its job.   
I provide heights from 40mm (gives enough clearance for an N-scale diesel loco to pass just under it) to just a couple of mm. Change them and adapt them to your needs all you want.

description.text: a 3D printable laptop stand, i designed it around the appoximate size of a macbook air, but should work fine for any smaller laptop (ultrabooks, chrombooks, MacBooks, etc.). I have included the Solidworks files you want to make adjustments on it to suit your wants/needs, feel free to download and use how ever you see fit just give a shoutout.

Slightly changed but greatly improved version of Shape Lock Chain I
http://youtu.be/yalD33QPM94 I've cut away a tiny bit of the very last locking element such that the chain can be locked end to end to a loop. This is the single point friction lock for the whole chain.

For the shown bracelet you'll need:
  • 16 main links
  • 16 locker parts
  • 16 axles
    For the axles you can use 3mm diameter printing filament cut to the right length. PLA plastic can be scratched with a knife and broken.
    You could also use brass, wood, bamboo, steel, carbon-fiber or some other material for your axles.

remixed_from.author: Brendantang
remixed_from.title: 10th Doctor Who Sonic Screwdriver head for a Marker

description.text: I wanted to make a screwdriver cigar holder as a "Congratulations" gift for a friend. Resizing some of the existing models didn't work for me so I remixed a few instead. Thanks to Brendantang with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:509880 for the top and hobinjk with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5308 for the bottom tip. Overall, this comes out to just over 12" long tip to tip and fits roughly a 13 cm x 3 cm cylinder inside the body of the screwdriver handle. The bottom end is a bit scary since it has those thin spires. Will take a little sanding as the tolerances aren't perfect.

comments.text: You might want to check the dimensions of the files before you print it I just assembled mine and it came out over 18"  long and about 3" in diameter.  Other that that it looks pretty good I had to sand the heck out of the round cap to get it to fit, and the body printed without the hole for the top to fit in, That might have been my slicer though.
comments.author: Miertam

comments.text: I just downloaded the files and checked the length in Sketchup.  The tube handle comes out to a nice even 6 inches from tip to tip and the topper (without cap) is about 5 so I think the dimensions are okay.  I think your slicer may have had a little too much to drink that day...  As far as sanding, I have a tendency to make tolerances too tight and then sand them into place.  I prefer it to having loose parts.  That's just design preference, I guess.

title: Deep thought / Hitchhiker's guide to the Galaxy / 42

description.text:
This model was inspired by Deep Thought featuring in the "Hitchhiker's guide to the Galaxy" (2005) movie. Those who have not yet seen the movie -- DO see the movie ^^ Those who have seen it -- get the model xD I am not too much of an artist, so the representation is quite basic. There are three versions, that I have uploaded: 1 -- The initial model (Will never be printed by me, as the bottom of the head is still too flat).
2 -- The model that includes all supports for printing that I could've come up with.
3 -- The model that includes the supports for the head, but has none for the mouth (I did not take the chance to print this one yet).

The things presented on the photos were printed in 0.1mm layer, 100mm/s speed, 230 temp and 30% infill.  
The smaller one has no mouth supports. I think the mouth should be fine without any support at larger scales as well. So, try model 3 first :)  
I would highly admire any mods on this one:)  
P.S. Waitin' for Colorfabb Copperfill fillament :p

title: Printable Robot Arm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my first try to build a printable robot arm.
I was inspired by the demo of zortrax, but it's my own design. It is not tested yet, I'm still printing.
It should fit together but.
There are 8 608zz ball bearing required to mount the arms.
2x M8x60mm and 2x M8x65mm screws and 4 Nuts (best case self locking) The main motors are Nema17, for the forearm I plan to use a Nema11 with a planetary gear. The screws to mout the parts together are M4 REMEMBER THIS is untested! The forearm and gripper are also not finished yet. first test of the basis with the first joint:
http://youtu.be/O5_gnh2r2Gw 14.12.2014
I updated some files... most should fit now, but still a work in progress. 16.12.2014
all parts are printed:
http://youtu.be/XGjULACXRRQ 19.12.2014
The second part:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:601036 I started a hackaday project:
http://hackaday.io/project/3800-3d-printable-robot-arm You can find a overview on my blog:
http://chaozlabs.blogspot.de/2015/01/3d-printable-robot-arm.html

description.text:
le trou au centre du bouton est un carré de 6mm de coté.
rayon 20mm et une hauteur de 30 mm

So you want your prints to be precise and nice, right? Print Kalibr1. This is the first step, it has to be 2*1cm, if so you know your steps are OK. You want the inner hole to be perfectly round so that you know you have no play in x and y axes. Try to destroy it, just cut it along the layers to know how well they stick together. Print Kalibr2. This is just about supports and setting them up. Print Kalibr3. You should be able to put those radiuses together nicely. If there is a gap in the middle your objects are a bit too large (too much material extruded) and vice versa. If you succeed in printing all of them then you are ready to print virtually anything. And if you think that the supports are too hard then you should watch this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0lRz6sURO4&feature=youtu.be

title: Printrbot Jr. Acrylic Printbed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An experimental printbed for printing PLA with no heated bed. The first layer extrudes into the engraved grid and the textured acrylic adds extra grip. So far has worked with every print. 
Idea inspired by early MakerBot Cupcake acrylic printbed and the perforated phenolic printbeds used in Afinia printers.

To be lasercut from 6mm sandblasted or textured acrylic. EPS as shown for use with a ULS VersaLaser according to the following colors:
Red (outline): vector cut
Blue (10mm squares): heavy vector engrave
Green (2mm squares): medium vector engrave Avoid situations where a hot pinthead is parked in close proximity to the acrylic for a prolonged time as this may melt the acrylic.

For an iPhone4 version, go here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:65553
For an iPod Touch Gen4 version, go here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:68536 It's a case for an iPhone5. There are many important differences between this case and others on Thingiverse. The most sensitive part of an iPhone is the edge of the glass. (The face of the glass is also sensitive, but we can't cover that!) Other cases do not offer much protection for the edge of the glass. Also other cases have a sloppy fit. This case solves both problems. This case is made from two halves that slide onto the phone and snap together. When it snaps together, there is a strangely satisfying click! The two halves fit together very tightly, and will not accidentally come loose.

Print both halves separately. Because the surface finish is super important for a good looking case, use the highest resolution settings and slow down the speed. Having the filament diameter dialed in is also important. Do not use rafts or supports. This is designed with "mouse ears" included in the STL. After printing, some minor filing/sanding might be required on the dovetail joint. Also, break off the built-in "mouse ears" and file/sand down the spot where they broke off. The amount of filing/sanding should be minimal. It takes me about 2 minutes to do this step. I printed this on a Replicator 2 in PLA with ReplicatorG/Skeinforge. My settings were:
Layer Height: 0.1
Infill: 100%
Shells: 0
Feedrate: 40
Travel Feedrate: 75 Remember to get your temperature and filament diameter set appropriately for your filament. On my Replicator 2 it took about 3-3.5 hours for each half. About 6.5 to 7 hours total. Taking the case off of the phone can be tricky the first time you do it. What you do is pry up two of the dovetails on the same side with shim-like things. They don't need to be raised very much, just so they clear the case back. With the shims in place, just pull the halves apart. Make sure that your pry-bar/shim will not scratch the iPhone. I have used things like bamboo skewers, saxophone reeds, and nylon zip-ties for this task. I have included the Solidworks file for this design, so people can modify it. There are two elements in the design called "Top Cutoff" and "Bottom Cutoff". Use the suppress/unsuppress functions to basically select which half of the case is "active", then save the STL file for that half.

comments.text: You seem very savvy with the controls on a 3D printer and I was wondering if you might know how to fix flare ups. Flare ups being, when one is printing at an angle, and the edge of the print after the nozzle goes by, bends up (about .62 mm) to the point that if the nozzle goes over it it ends up going into it, and knocking the print off the bed, sometimes I get lucky and it just melts through though. I have a Maker Gear M2 and use simplify 3D as my slicer software. Any help would be greatly appreciated.
comments.author: Gregory_E_Nator

comments.text: Hmmm, this is a hard one.  The problem comes from the plastic itself.  It shrinks as it cools, and if it shrinks unevenly then you get warping.  In most cases, the warping causes it to detach from the build platform but in some cases it can happen elsewhere.  A common place for it to happen in this print is at the curved sides/corners, just a couple of mm up from the build platform.

comments.author: jpgm

comments.text: Here's the thing...  You're over-extruding, and that is the reason for it requiring a lot of filing and a tight fit.  In your slicer, increase your filament diameter to compensate.  You will never get a correct fit without doing that.  I'm not sure what you mean by "hollow thick walls", but the instructions say to use 100% infill and 1 total outside shell.  If you don't do that then the case will be weak and could cause the tabs to break off.  You could also be bending the tabs back too far (they only need to bend about 2 mm).  Even if you had straight ends, you would still need to print with 100% infill and 1 total shell to get the proper strength to protect your phone.

remixed_from.author: enif
remixed_from.title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

description.text:
Ever tried to swipe through a musical score on your tablet while playing? Of course, now there's a solution for that, the "AirTurn". Except sometimes when browsing you need to go back and forth. Enter the "Airturn Two Pedal Board Kit". Of course, this costs a fair bit of money and still will only turn the pages for one band member's tablet. Enter the iTurn. Based on the LadyAda Bluefruit EZ-key, a Bluetooth HID, it contains two Bluetooth devices (or pretty much as many as you'd like) so now everyone can be literally on the same page when playing, thanks to iTurn. A big thanks goes to "enif" for the flexible battery holders used in this project! Bill of materials
Approximately 150 g of PLA
2 Adafruit EZ-Key Bluefruit
1 red led
1 kohm resistor
2 click buttons (momentary close)
1 Power switch Drawn in FreeCAD v0.14. Let me know if you need the CAD original to work on the design!

The latest version of EZ-Key is pretty much already set up for use.
Input #0 is "up" and #1 is "down". This works fine with apps like "PDF Expert" for iPad.

title: Art Deco Vase

description.text:
A small Art Deco style vase suitable to give as a gift.
The fan parts are tapered so they are flush with the body at the base but stand out at the top.
I've printed mine in typical Art Deco colors of black, teal and pearl.
Also posted is the Blender rendering of the vase before I made it for comparison.

title: I3 Rework / Wilson X-Carriage for T2.5 belt (with SW source)

description.text:
This version of the I3 Rework / Wilson X-Carriage should be functionally identical to mrice's Wilson one but for T2.5 belt (his is for GT2).  
On the aesthetics, I kinda went a bit nuts and chamfered various edges to give the final object smooth edges.   
Thanks for looking and hope this helps someone out.

I printed this in PLA with 0.75 infill, 0.4 mm nozzle @190C, Bed @ 40C, and my usual smear of glue stick to help the first layer hold.  
I used Repetier 0.95F / Slic3r 1.0.0RC2. It sliced fine, but one of the recesses to the left of the lower LM8UU got filled in a bit. it didn't affect the final print so I went with it. One day I will try it with a newer Slic3r.  
I used M4 pan head pozidrive screws to bolt the extruder on, The heads were a little to large for the design, so i had to spin them in a drill & file them to reduce the head size a little.

author: ddes98

description.text: A printable letter opener where you insert a piece of a 10 mm snap-off blade during the print.

At my office I open lots of letters, so I came up with this letter opener which uses a really sharp and durable blade from a 10 mm snap-off blade knife. The opener is designed to cut in a movement towards the body.
  • Start the print, make sure you have at least 1 mm top and bottom shell. Slice with grooved side down.
  • Prepare a piece of blade and tape with the sticky side down.
  • Pause at approximately 70% of the print, and tape down the blade in the space as depicted.
  • Finish the print, the plastic should now print on top of the painters tape. Sand and polish until the letter opener feels nice to use.
  • Bring it to the office and show off your super duper sharp letter opener, maybe trade one for a lunch.
    • If you want to make it possible to exchange the blade, it is possible to fold a few layers of tape and place it sticking out from the blade compartment. When the print is finished, pull out the tape and insert a blade. I haven't tried this myself, so if it doesn't work, remix!

title: Two Up Y Axis Pillow Blocks

description.text:
This mod was specifically designed to fix the problem of y-axis wobble in the Two Up. These pillow blocks raise the bed about 3mm and allow 4 linear bearings to support the y-axis. This removes most of the wobble experienced due to the moment exerted by the belt on the right side of the table. You need to buy 2 more LM8LUU bearings for this mod.
16 M4 screws and 16 m4 nuts
12 M3 screws and 12 M3 nuts This mod is completely removable!

This was made to fix a common problem. If you wish to use 4 bearings print 2 of the dual pillow blocks and 2 of the dual pillow blocks in a mirrored orientation. You can also experiment with using 3 linear bearings using the single pillow block. Once printed mount your bearings using the M3 screws and nuts. This will allow the case to shrink around the bearing. Arrange the pillow blocks into the slots in the wood frame for alignment. Mark and drill 16 M4 holes. Insert pillow blocks and slide 8mm shaft through the bearings to ensure perfect alignment and bolt down. PRINTING ADVICE.
if you are having issues with the print pulling up on the first layer try using a 1mm brim. This will cause the small slot to fill up and makes it much easier.

text = Yolanda

My Delta Bot needs a "knee". that's the joint between the driving motor, and the "ankle", which is the lower leg of the two legs of the delta bot. This thing is a simple "knee". It has a notch in it so it can be easily connected to other things that have the matching "key". You simply slip a piece of smooth rod, or dowel, or whatever you have that can rotate within the hole, put some bar ends on the axle (like a Clevis joint), and you've now go a knee! UPDATE: 30012011
Added the _half version of the disc axle. The full one is hard to print as a single piece, depending on the quality and type of support/raft your printer has. The 'half' version allows you to print it flat. Just print two of them, and put their flat sides together. You can glue together, or just let the piece that has the key hold them together, depending on your needs.

1) Look at your Delta Bot pieces laying in the corner
2) Print 3 of these out
3) Print out some clevis joints
4) Put an axle through the center hole
5) Slip the elbow end of the Clevis Joint onto the axle.
6) Slip rods into the end of the Clevis Joint
7) Connect those rods to something else
8) Rejoice!

description.text:
I was having problems with the original design from BPopilek, where the spool would randomly fall off the holder. So I edited the design, and made make it longer, so the spool would have a better center of gravity, and not fall off the holder as easily. I made two versions, one where I added 20mm of length, and another with 35mm of length. Either one should work fine. I just designed the longer one for the added security. The bearings can be purchased here: (You will need 2 sets)

Due to the recent incidents (things appearing on ebay) I just want to make something very clear:
I do not allow any commercial use of my STL-files, my designs and my photos! Description:
Oh no, not again another ball bearing... Sorry, but I just have to show my final design. jonathanw's comment on my last ball bearing ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:57762 ) gave me new ideas. I reduced the bearing to three parts. The inner ring is now made of one piece and need not to be snapped together. Unfortunately the assembly is a little bit more complicated. I made a simple assembly tool that makes things easier. Take a look at this video for the assembly sequence: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P5VLo87xurM As requested I added another assembly tool (roud support). PS: Thanks jonathanw for leading me to a new idea!

• Print all parts (layer height schould be 0.1mm)
  • Assemble like seen in the video
  • Rock 'n Roll

description.text: Cookie cutter form " Ukrainian Trident "

Perito Moreno Glacier in Argentina constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 2.4 million polygons). Besides the better accuracy, this version covers a little more area than the original 3 arc-second file. This model was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL. See the time-lapse video of printing Perito Moreno on a Lulzbot Taz 5 here: https://youtu.be/oKOYGI5yQeo

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.
